sense.name: a span of time when the sun is up, daylight
sense.commentary: DAY[+event]LIGHT[+quantity][+span][+temporal][+daylight] [+state][+temporal][+daylight] daylight hours The time after sunrise and before sunset while it is light outside
sense.examples: The dawn turned night into day. It is easier to make the repairs by the light of day. We hastened back to the cabin while we still had some day left.

sense.name: one complete rotation of a planet on its axis, especially Earth
sense.commentary: DAY [+quantity][+span][+temporal][+unit][+24_hours] [+event][+physical][+rotation][+complete][+around_axis][+planetary] the period of time taken by a particular planet to make a complete rotation on its axis (On earth, 24hrs) Note: is used in the plural as a unit of time, 'five days'
sense.examples: Your swelling should go down in three days. The visitors left two days later. I'm expecting the package to arrive any day now. (its arrival is what is being characterized temporally) The journey takes five days by horseback. How long is a day on Jupiter?

sense.name: a continuous span of regular human activity, usually falling within a 24-hour period
sense.commentary: DAY[+event][+quantity][+span][+temporal][+activity][+regular][+human] Note: refers to a regular continuous span of human activity, not necessarily during daylight hours Note: occurs in the singular, it refers to activities within a span, not a unit of time per se.
sense.examples: My day began at 11:00. It was the longest day of his life. She called it a day and went to bed. It was a busy day on the stock exchange. What a day the stock market had!

sense.name: a defining or characterized span of time
sense.commentary: DAY[+event][+quantity][+span][+temporal][+characterized][+by_trait] Note: often refers to a historical epoch, but also could be a briefer span in the life of an individual
sense.examples: Those were the days. These days it is not unusual. In the day of the dinosaurs there were no cars, George. In the days of the Roman Empire there were also no cars, George. He was a successful pianist in his day. After that day, he never believed another word she said.

sense.name: official observance, e.g., holiday
sense.commentary: DAY[+event][+official][+observance] a day assigned to a particular purpose or observance
sense.examples: Mother's Day is coming up soon, did you get a gift? I prefer Christmas Day over New Years Day. On Earth Day we're all going to walk to work. The two schools have different graduation days.

sense.name: astronomy: sidereal day
sense.commentary: DAY[+event][+physical][+rotation][+planetary][+sidereal] the time for one complete rotation of the earth relative to a particular star, about 4 minutes shorter than a mean solar day - because earth is moving around sun as it continues its daily rotation, thus affecting orientation wrt the star.
sense.examples: The sidereal day is the length of time taken for the vernal equinox to return your celestial meridian. A sidereal day is the rotation of the Earth measured relative to the stars.

sense.commentary: was a Proper Noun, we are not coding these

sense.name: a state of opportunity, chance to be heard
sense.examples: He deserves his day in court. Every dog has his day.
